results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a snapshot of a family voyage on board a cruise ship, street scenes of a Dragster bicycle and scenes from a wedding at the Royal Mint in Melbourne. There are good examples of Melbourne architecture, fashion and Australian cars, reflective of the time.

The film begins with scenes on board a cruise ship. We see dolphins swimming alongside the ship as Maurie and his son share an affectionate moment on the deck. Val finds her sea legs and relaxes on a sun lounge or deck chair. Passengers enjoy diving into and swimming in the cruise ship’s swimming pool.

Back on dry land, a street scene shows a boy (possibly Maurie’s son) riding along the footpath on a Dragster bicycle. Parked along the side of the road we see great examples of cars c1960s. We see an Australian Ford Fairlaine, an Australian Ford Falcon, an FC Holden Station Wagon and possibly an FE Holden. There is also a HK Holden Belmont or Kingswood c1968, and a Vauxhall. The family cat and dog also make a brief appearance.

The film shows guests arriving to a wedding ceremony being held at the Royal Mint in Melbourne. The Mint was opened in 1872 and became a Registry of Civil Marriages in the 1970s. We see the Renaissance Revival architecture and surrounding buildings, as well as the coat of arms.

Guests arrive and greet each other outside the registry. Inside we see the wedding cake, guests enjoying themselves and the hospitality arrangement at the reception.

Originally made on 8mm film

Selected highlights list:
00:01:41:00 Maurie and son deck side

00:01:47:00 Boy on a Dragster Bicycle with vintage cars parked alongside.

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Thailand.

The film has the occasional hair in the gate and some rough hand-held techniques.

The film opens with street scenes somewhere in Thailand. We see bicycle tuk tuks, smiling children and a policeman.

A road trip includes a stop over to make an offering at a street side Buddhist shrine. We see local buses and vehicles including a Volkswagen Kombi van.

The film shows a boat trip along a congested river, which could be in the area of the historic city of Ayutthaya. We see bridges, speed boats, welcome signs, vendors selling postcards and a welcome sign reading “Dummearn Souvernir”. A jolly Maurie Fields smiles as water from the river splashes past his face.

There is a visit to a temple which could possibly be Wat Phra Si Sanphet on the site of the old Royal Palace in Thailand’s ancient capital of Ayutthaya.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film

Selecteed highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Bicycle tuk tuks, children, policeman

00:01:54:00 Profile of Maurie Fields on the river

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Bangkok, Thailand.

The film opens with scenes shot from what could be the floor of a high-rise hotel balcony or window. We see city views of Bangkok showing buildings and cars on the street below, as well as what could be the Royal Bangkok Sports Club and racetrack. There is also evidence of some colonial architecture.

A tourist boat trip through the khlongs (canals) of what could be the Chao Phraya River in the Thonburi area of Bangkok, Thailand, shows snippets of the way of life at the water’s edge. Along the way of the canals and river, we see tropical water plants, temples, traditional and motorised canoes, and square, fishing bag-nets. There are scenes of wooden stilt houses, longtail boats, washing lines and river side stalls.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film

Selected highlight:
00:01:23:00 Temple and wooden structures along the waterside

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snippet from a family holiday in Bangkok, Thailand.

Some of the footage is grainy and underexposed with some very unstable handheld sequences.

The film opens with a Bangkok street scene of a man holding a python wrapped around his arms and neck. We are then taken to the Grand Palace in the Phra Nakon district of Bangkok. The Grand Palace has been the official residence of the Kings of Siam (Thailand) since 1782. The King, his court, and his royal government were based on the grounds of the palace until 1925.

We see the grounds and buildings that comprise the palace, including Wat Phra Kaew (the Temple of the Emerald Buddha), Chakri Maha Prasat Hall, the Belfry and Hor Phra Monthian Dharma. We see the beautiful glazed tiles and gold leaf facade of Wat Phra Kaew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha). We see tourists taking photos and wandering around the site and there is scaffolding surrounding what could be Phra Siratana Chedi.

A very colorful Val Jellay, wearing a Kaftan style dress, poses on stairs leading to the entrance of the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. She entertains her son and the camera operator while she strikes various traditional Thai-style dance poses.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Matthew Flinders: bi-centennial celebrations]
results.brief_description: Shows footage of the bicentennial celebrations in Great Britain of the explorer Matthew Flinders (born 1774-1814), including the “Explorer’s Window” at Lincoln Cathedral, several exhibits and an art exhibition detailing his life, and finally a presentation of a Memorial Stone by Sir Murray Porter to Lincolnshire to commemorate Matthew Flinders’ birthday. Commentary by John Hyfield. NB: No title or credits and film ends abruptly
results.description: Shows footage of the bicentennial celebrations in Great Britain of the explorer Matthew Flinders (born 1774-1814), including the “Explorer’s Window” at Lincoln Cathedral, several exhibits and an art exhibition detailing his life, and finally a presentation of a Memorial Stone by Sir Murray Porter to Lincolnshire to commemorate Matthew Flinders’ birthday. Commentary by John Hyfield. NB: No title or credits and film ends abruptly

results.title: [Matthew Flinders: bi-centennial celebrations 1974]
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development, Department of Agriculture and Country Roads Board
results.brief_description: Captures the various bi-centennial celebrations that were organised in Victoria to commemorate the birth of Captain Matthew Flinders. Includes footage of the Shrine; Mornington beach; Arthur’s Seat; Port Philip Bay; Station Peaks; Flinder’s Street Station; St Paul’s Cathedral; Swanston street; and the Matthew Flinders torch relay. Leading Victorian figures appear unveiling commemorative plaques. This is an un-edited film without a soundtrack which documents many of the celebrations.

results.title: [Maryvale Paper Mill]
results.brief_description:
Untitled silent film with occasional intertitles.
Of historical value this film shows Sir Herbert Gupp(?) with Rotarians at the Maryvale Paper Mill on 20 February 1941.
The Mill was built in 1937 at a cost of 400,000 pounds. Also shows homes of the workmen and staff.
No credits available.

results.title: [Marriage counselling]
results.creator_credit: CBS Television, Irving Gitlin and Henwar Rodakiewicz
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Search”.
Illustrates new methods of helping people avoid or overcome marital unhappiness. Presented under the guidance of the Marriage Council or Philadelphia and the University of Pennsylvania, School of Medicine, this television report explains the workings of a marriage council and discusses some of the important findings which have emerged from professional counselling. Illustrates the problems reacted by wives working, infidelity, attitudes towards children, and those difficulties that arise from the conflict between reality and the false impression held by many young people today.
